name: Craig LaBan
bio: Hungry Man for Hire, Deadline Drinker, Duck Influencer, Hoagie-centric, Phila Inquirer restaurant critic. “Destiny has brought me this lamb chop.”

social_posts.post_text:
Ever travel to sunny paradise for a conference only to be trapped in a meeting room for most of the daylight hours? That just about sums up my touring status over the past 4 days in South Beach. I did get to spend quality time with some respected colleagues, and also snagged some precious early morning hours of sun and sand. And yes, I experienced some memorable meals, too.

The creamy raw snap of this deeply scored bigfin reef squid with minty huacatay, lulo and finger limes was easily one of the most spectacular bites of the week, a stellar example of the Nikkei-style Peruvian sushi at @itamaemiami, whose al fresco dining room sits among the palm trees of a luxury outdoor mall. The citrusy 🐙 bañadito, geoduck clam rice and “daily catch fish heads” were also fantastic.

I’m also still humming over last night’s savory-sweet “dulce” frita Cubana @reydelasfritas, a power combo of maduro plantains with a chorizo burger + a fistful of crunchy shoestring potatoes on a bun at this Little Havana classic.

It seems like yesterday we got here for a perfect first night of Cuban food, cocktails and live music @cafelatrovamiami. But this morning it was already time to go. And you know what? A plate of flaky, fresh tostones and moros for breakfast with café con leche at the airport branch of @cafelacarreta is not a bad farewell Miami meal, at all.

I always wanted to do a Seven Fishes dinner and actually stumbled into a good one this week @messinasocialclub. We’d randomly reserved for a revisit that night; I’d neglected to look at the fine print on the Resy confirmation, so… we went with it. To be honest, $135 for the menu was pricier than I might have knowingly gone for ahead of time. But chef @ewkonrad is one of most talented young chefs and his team delivered a memorable meal with some modern takes on the seafood bounty  theme of this South Philly Christmas week tradition.

Tops among them was this fantastic octopus bolognese with squid ink gnocchi sardi, crowned with a regal little whole baby octopus, stained ebony black from its inky braise. It was tender and flavorful, and the pasta was full of savor with a perfect seafood undertow. 
Also… 
-a hiramasa tartare served like a taco inside a shiso leaf; a plump mussel stuffed like a deviled egg and a snappy cube of shrimp cocktail terrine
-fried potato terrine (not really a “latke”) with lobster and roe
-capery monkfish piccata, the fish cooked just right
-slow-roasted moist swordfish with caponata
-the Resume Gap, a cocktail with  gentian, punt e mes and chili, one of several excellent creative cocktails sipped that night

Matzo ball soup for two with sourdough toast,
confit chicken and smoked schmaltz was a soulful way to mark one of our last meals of 2022 with some haute deli romance @redcrestkitchen. 

This recently opened neighborhood restaurant and bar in the former Bainbridge Street Barrel House space is definitely not a deli. The menu ranges from crudo to pastas (try the chestnut agnolotti with braised lamb) and tenu ours trout. But on this night we indulged in more Ashkenazi-inspired flavors there, from the smoked short rib with rye spaeztle, pickled red cabbage and Comté foam (a reimagined Reuben) to a sublime chicken liver toast stylishly dotted with Concord grape jelly dusted with grated smoked peanuts. It was essentially a highbrow PB&J (even if I’m plenty happy with basic PB&Js, too. They’re among my favorite deadline day comfort foods). 

Redcrest also delivered some very clever vegetarian cooking with this n’duja spiced squash toast, which had a lush texture and a zesty flavor that did not miss the usual pork at all. The cocktails were fun, the beef and wine list is full of good choices (a glass of Chateau Saint Julian was just right for the short rib). The only real disappointment at our first meal was the porchetta, which had great flavor, but none of the crispy skin exterior I usually covet with that Roman specialty.

But I’ll definitely be back!

“There was a need for a good Mexican sandwich.” 

I could not agree more with chef @jcarlosaparicio,
who’s taken matters into his own baker’s hands @elchingonphilly,
his charming new all-day cafe near East Passyunk where he’s focused on baking fresh rolls for the perfect cemita, the signature sandwich from his native state of Puebla, as well as sweet concha rolls like this one, encrusted with cinnamon-scented blue corn pinole and stuffed with Nutella pastry cream for dessert.

You may know Aparicio from his long tenure as chef of the Italian-themed Tredici/Zavino group, or his role as the baker who launched Parc’s French bread program. But this is the first time in his three decade career that he’s cooking the food of his childhood, and he’s diving deep into Mexican traditions, along with the help of his sisters Margarita and Berenice. The menu goes into several intriguing directions - classics like menudo, cochinita pibil; vegan variations on pozole and aguachiles, tostadas topped with rabbit tinga and plenty of great tacos, too, including a knock-out Árabes wrapped in fresh flour tortillas infused with a hint of sourdough, which was novel to me. (“Hey, I’m a baker,” shrugs Aparicio).

I loved all the great flavors here, especially the Clásica cemita built around perfectly fried, tender chicken cutlets topped with a cool mop of shredded Oaxaca cheese and citrusy papalo herbs. But the sandwich I suddenly can’t stop thinking about now is the cemita with arrachera, a skirt steak marinated in charred chile recado negro rehydrated with vinegar and herbs that comes with a side of roasty salsa macha. Splash that salsa on liberally, as it helps that smoky beef glow. And you’ll know. That wish for a great Mexican sandwich? It’s been answered.

Check out my full review of El Chingón, to be published very soon at @phillyinquirer

What’s better than a cumin-scented platter of great Uzbek plov? One you can dive into 24 hours a day. 
Northeast Philly continues to be one of the city’s great, unsung culinary destinations, and @plov_house_philadelphia, a humble but delicious Uzbek diner that’s open all hours of the day, is more proof - especially in an era when 24-hour dining options are dwindling. 

While this little strip mall restaurant specializes in the signature hearty pilaf, each grain of cumin-scented rice glazed in the fatty richness of tender beef juices, laced with sweet carrots and raisins, it has a full menu of worthy other traditional specialties. Char-kissed kebabs. Soulful lagman soup with chewy hand-rolled noodles. Steamy manti and flaky samsa. I also loved the doughy roll-up stuffed with beef and potatoes called honim, which looked like the steamy love child of a strudel and a dumpling. 

Check out my full piece on Plov House @phillyinquirer today.  And thanks so much to @thenortheastlife for the hot tip on Plov House. Because, like I said, Northeast Philly rocks!

I was so mesmerized by the artistry of this server making trays full of perfect wontons when I stopped by @djkitchenus for takeout a few months ago, that I needed to return to taste these delicate dumpling beauties fresh in house. We had them in fiery red chili oil, and also bobbing in golden broth, and they did not disappoint. 

In fact, *everything* was a delight at this hidden Szechuan gem, which has one of the most mysterious entrances in the area and appears at first glance to be a seemingly inaccessible storefront right off City Line Ave. in the front of the onramp to the Schuylkill Expressway. You need to park upstairs in front of the new Chick-Fil-A beside the Target, navigate the narrow unmarked walk around Chipotle’s filthy rear trash bins, and then tack around the little sidewalk behind that strip of chain restaurants down and under that building. Despite its out of the way entrance, the dining room inside DJ is bright and modern and quite bustling on Friday night, many of them Chinese exchange students from St. Joe’s University who live in nearby Presidential City. 

Aside from the wontons, we loved the xiaolongbao, which were smaller than most soup dumplings I’ve had, but nicely shaped and filled with a beautifully flavored broth. The cold sesame noodles were firm and snappy. The spicy Phoenix chicken was similar to a Chongqing, crispy and laced with peppers, but with a sweeter kiss of five spice and fermented black beans in the batter. The crispy spicy shrimp were perfectly fried - greaseless and moist and humming with ma la spice. And really, we just scratched the surface. DJ has a huge menu of largely Szechuan classics, and I plan to return to explore them all, but this kitchen also handles Americanized Cantonese classics well, too. Best orange beef in Philly? It’s definitely a contender. Now you know how to get there.

“I keep it simple, and I keep it busy.”
 
It’s hard to argue with @speer_fit when you get to @pizzawestchester for an afternoon 🍕 snack and find a line of patient customers practically out the door. There are only three choices for pizzas here - plain, pepperoni and white. No bougie toppings. No seasonal flourishes. Just the very basics. Elemental pizza as you know it. But pizzaiolo Speer Madanat reliably sells-out his 100 pies a day, all of them ordered walk-in, cash only, and with nowhere to eat in this no-frills storefront but at the steel table perched beside the front window. 

I recommend you do dig in right there because there is nothing quite like a simple pizza done right when it’s straight out of the oven. Speer’s pies are crispy, roasty, well-baked rounds that simply dial-in all the details. The Italian tomatoes bursting with vivid red sweetness. The pepperoni pie topped with the best cup-and-char saucers of pepperoni goodness. The white pie layered with a thick smear of sweet ricotta sparked with a fistful of grated cheese and a drizzle of roasted garlic oil. But the best choice here is ultimately the plain red pie - layered with multiple kinds of low-moisture mozzarella to lock in the torn nubs of fresh fior di latte so that their milky sweetness melts without weeping. Speer, who by the end of his shift is covered with flour from the waist down, monitors each pie meticulously inside the double decks of his electric oven, set for 596-degrees, shuffling them around from side to side and front to back so that each rounds hits its peak level of heat-speckled doneness without over-charring. 

Turn the sound on in slide 2 to hear the beautiful “Crunch!” of Speer’s pizza wheel rolling through a perfectly roasted crust. And then set your GPS for West Chester. This is proof that basic pizza can be destination pizza, too.

Can’t believe it’s already been a year since I went to Thailand to follow @kuhnnok as she visited Bangkok, her home town in Southern Thailand and the islands in search of inspiration for @kalayaphilly 2.0. It was easily one of the best assignments I’ve ever had the privilege of writing (“Nok Takes Flight”). Now look what an incredible new version of her restaurant she has created in Fishtown with her partners @dhrestaurants. I loved it in my opening review in February @phillyinquirer. But Kalaya recently opened for weekend lunch and you have to see this gorgeous space during the day as sunshine streams in through the skylight onto this airy room’s center court of palms. All the beautiful fixtures designed by @studio.briquette (like those soft sea foam green velvet banquettes trimmed with rattan) in this old warehouse space transformed by @stokesarchitecture come into full view.

The lunch menu is also distinct from dinner. It includes a fantastic Thai chicken biryani, very much inspired by the ones we tasted in the markets of Southern Thailand, especially on the island of Koh Yao Noi, which is predominantly Muslim, where we ate it for breakfast.  Nok’s pad Thai goong is also featured at lunch only, and it is stellar, especially because it features one of those grilled river prawns, whose sweet meat cradles a pool of molten orange fat in its head. Also, can’t miss those gui chai garlic chive cakes, the ducky spice of laab ped, fried rice with pork sausage and the grilled skirt steak, a crowd-pleaser that hits next level zing with a generous splash of tangy nam jim jaew chili sauce. 

As I wrote in my earlier review, I think Kalaya 2.0 is the most impactful new restaurant on a national scale to land in Philly since Zahav. It is also 99% gluten-free, and if there is a more exciting gluten-free restaurant anywhere I’ve not yet found it. The light of day has revealed even more of its charms.

Took a jaunt earlier this week down to Washington D.C.  to check out a couple @beardfoundation nominees, and I was thrilled with @albiwashdc. This modern Middle Eastern restaurant from @chefmichaelrafidi is very much in the zone of Philly’s @zahavrestaurant and @surayaphilly, but explores those flavors through the lens of Rafidi’s Palestinian American roots. The airy room is modern, colorful and bright, with live fire in the open kitchen lending an extra warmth to this contemporary space in the Navy Yard. The service was graceful and outgoing. The drinks softened the mood (loved the Stronghold’s very loose riff on a Sazerac with an arak mist and tahini-brown butter-washed bourbon; and I’m a fan of that @chateaumusarlebanon white).

But the cooking… just spectacular. The smoked carrot vegan riff on kibbeh naya may be the best vegetable thing I’ve eaten all year, fragrant with earthy spice,and moist enough that it had the spreadability and texture of the meat tartare it was replacing. Also fantastic: the mini sfeeha lamb pies with toum; the silky hummus with the Atlantic Coast flair of Sea Island white peas and a briny sweet crab for garnish. I devoured the cinnamon-scented grape leaves topped with oxtail. And the “BBQ’d lamb” main course was a showstopper with its multi-level lamb presentation - chunks of loin and meltingly soft belly alternated on the skewer, more lamb bits in the side of rice with almonds. But I also especially enjoyed the pair of lamb kebabs wrapped around cinnamon sticks, which brought me right back to El Babur in Yokne’am Illit, Israel.

Tableside Turkish coffee service and a chocolate-covered frozen halva bar to finish had me convinced: Rafidi is a legit contender for Best Chef in the Mid-Atlantic. This was one of the best, most soulful meals I’ve had in D.C. in recent memory.

¡From Mexico to Philly, con amor!!! 
The journey @nichojimenez took from tiny San Mateo Ozolco in Puebla to becoming a @beardfoundation nnominated chef @cantina.la.martina.philly was a long and arduous road that began 25 years ago. What a privilege I had to retrace that path and accompany Dionicio back to his roots, a place thousands of other Mexican-born residents now in Philly also call their hometown, a little village on the slopes of Popocatépetl’s fuming volcano peak. 
I got a chance to tell Dionicio’s tale today @phillyinquirer in Part I of a series of Philadelphia stories from Mexico. Tap my bio to check it out online, along with a companion piece on the 21 best things I ate and drank while I was there with Dionicio and @davidsurop of @tequilasphilly, who led us on an adventure across tequila and mezcal country that’s publishing next week. The pictures online and in next Sunday’s print Inquirer from my colleague and travel pal @jessicagriffin_photo are phenomenal. 
These photos, though, are mine, and are just a fraction of the beautiful things I experienced as we traveled from Oaxaca to Puebla City, Cholula and San Mateo Ozolco. 
-Dionicio sipping fresh aguamiel nectar from an agave field in Oaxaca
-Atole tasting at La Atoleria, @tierradelsolrestaurante, Oaxaca 
-late night tacos de cabeza binge with Dionicio at Taqueria Viviana in Puebla
-tamales,
champurrado and a guajolota tamale sandwich from Israel Zuñiga’s cart  in Puebla
-Cemitas Mary in Cholula Market
-chicken mixiote, made by Dio’s mom Celia in San Mateo Ozolco
-Celia’s tortillas, made from heritage blue corn the family grows on their farm
-Popocatépetl, still smoking
-all the mezcal and songs with Dio’s fiance @aliceasaez1977 and singer Don Zenòn @losamantesezcal, Oaxaca
-Santo Dionicio in Puebla City

Mexico’s food scene is at an exciting crossroads as a generation of young chefs explores new ways to celebrate, preserve, and update pre-Hispanic foodways for modern diners. I ate amazing meals in all kinds of venues as I followed Philadelphia restaurateurs David Suro and Dionicio Jiménez through Michoacán, Jalisco, Oaxaca, and Puebla, from late night taquerias to the open-air kitchens of mezcal distilleries tucked away in the mountains. But several of the contemporary restaurants we visited also left a memorable mark, especially those where tradition and evolution working in tandem was the secret spice. 

Here are a few favorites from my camera’s vantage point…
In Guadalajara 
From @xokol_: Portrait of chef’s grandmother, Juana Segundo, holding a luminous blue ear of corn 
–tostada raspada with salsa macha chapulines, kanpachi and avocado; -huitlacoche quesadilla with bullseye masa, with side of crema from mountains of Jalisco
-making multi-colored tortillas with maiz pinto at the comal
From @_palreal_: lonche de pancita, a crusty, hollowed-out roll smeared with black beans and stuffed with meltingly tender confit pork and salsa verde 
From @restalcalde: mini-tlayuda topped with tuna, chapulines, salsa macha, and a flower shop’s worth of edible blooms
-cecina beef crackers

In Oaxaca 
-mini-snacks @criollodeoaxaca: juchiteco cheese ball, huitlacoche tetela, plantain empanada
-cocktail bar mise-en-place spices @criollodeoaxaca

In Morelia 
-@laconspiracion1809: huitlacoche zucchini timbale with chipotle crema in Morelia

It was a starry night in the mountains west of Michoacán, and we were waiting for the bats. So we drank mezcal. The bats *came* for their ancient pollinating dance, buzzing through the golden flowers blooming atop the agave’s tall quiote stalks, to collect nectar and roll in golden dust. So we drank more mezcal. And it was good.

I’d endured the worst van ride of my life - 2 ½ hours each way, bouncing off the seat as we navigated the rugged roads deep into Sierra Madre Occidental to get to Rancho El Limón. But it was so worth it. I got to meet the Bat Man of Mexico, the irrepressibly cheerful @batmanmedellin . And I also got to witness firsthand on a tour across Michoacán and Jalisco the the passion @davidsurop brings to his quest to celebrate the culture of agave spirits, the artisan producers carrying on traditions and his fierce advocacy for sustainable practices in a world in which the future of both tequila and mezcal are threatened by corporate forces and unwise agriculture. 

All the while, Suro was dealing with the recent devastating fire @tequilasphilly - navigating the recovery of Philly’s longest running Mexican restaurant and planning its comeback: “I can choose to curl up and cry, or I can come here to the source of our inspiration to rebuild.”

Please check out the full story just posted @phillyinquirer and the beautiful pictures @jessicagriffin_photo. The photos in this post are mine, and just a few of the most memorable moments from our trip. 

-an agave quiote in full bloom against a starry night
-sip of mezcal at dusk on Rancho El Limón
-the oak-fired stills @mezcaldonmateo 
-pechuga mezcal trickling off the still at Don Mateo
-87-year-old mezcalero, Don Lorenzo Virgen, atop his burro Pardo in Jalisco
-agave being loaded into the fire pit to roast for @siembraspirits Ancestral @cascahuin 
-rattlesnake mezcal at Jorge Pérez
-a mezcal still at Santos Juárez’s distillery in Jalisco
-agave being cleaved before distillation @cascahuin 
-an agave-pollinating long-tongue bat 🦇

We just put our son Arthur (@collegecoffeelife) on a plane to Lisbon for a brief “Maymester” study abroad and I’m so jealous. But the envy is tempered by the fact that we now have @gildaphilly, where I ate one of the most lovely lunches I’ve had in town in months. 

It all started with these perfect pastéis de Natas, their shatteringly crisp flaky shells harboring custard hearts that are luxuriously creamy and rich. But Gilda has plenty of worthy savory moves, too, each one very traditional, but simply well executed. Among the highlights…
-a caldo verde in which I could taste every element - its thin potato broth laces with shredded kale and the savory zing of rendered linguiça sausage rings. 
-fried bacalhau salt cod fritters that had the ideal balance of fluff and briny fish flakes
-char-grilled Piri Piri chicken blushes with its chili marinade and buried in a mountain of irresistibly hot and cunchy frites (#glutenfree!) 
-the Bifana sandwich of a tender, wine-marinated pork cutlet with Dijon on a Portuguese roll
-a cute little market shelf with imported products like Portuguese olive oil (always an incredible value) and tinned fish
-more pastéis de Natas for dessert
-I also covet the tinned fish wallpaper in the restroom

This is a great turnaround for a key Fishtown restaurant space, previously Sarvida and before that the no-tipping pioneer, Girard, where Gilda’s chef-partners Brian Oliveira and Brian Mattera actually met. They’re a couple now. And Gilda now definitely feels like the happy beginning of something new.

Whole fish is the best fish. No question about it. It’s juicier, more flavorful, and always a great party trick to navigate filleting one for your tablemates, provided you know where those bones are hiding. 

Here are just a few of the standout examples in Philly from the just past couple months: 
-whole sardines @mawnphilly grilled with Cambodian-style black pepper, salt and lime juice dip
-a wild two-pound branzino @lanimaphilly_ . If you’ve never had wild branzino, this plump and flavorful beauty whoops bass compared to the ubiquitous, bland farm-raised versions. Check in advance for availability, chef Gianluca Demontis occasionally special orders them for the weekend, and reliably sells out.
-roasted orata special with herbs, white wine and caper berries @zeppolirestaurant (since it’s always available, it’s more correctly a “not-special special”... except it’s really special.)
-salt-roasted whole kanpachi @vetricucinaphl , which then gets removed from the bones, wrapped in sea lettuce (a.k.a. seaweed) and cooked  a second time on the grill. It’s a cleverly progressive for one of Philly’s Italian classics, the final dish reminiscent of a maki roll.
-dorade @mawnphilly hit with hot sesame oil, ginger, garlic and Japanese herbs, a nod to chef Phila Lorn’s many years working for @zamakase 
-whole orata @irwinsupstairs , “Sicilian cut,” meaning it’s missing most of its  its center bones, and some juiceness of the others, but still bursting with herbal salsa verde zing and zesty sea bream goodness.

“A woman needs a man like a fish needs a bicycle.” 

That’s just one of the many bits of wisdom (& animatronic marketing genius) I gleaned yesterday @homeofguinness, which I got to tour with @artmax11. Also got to meet the famous Whistling Oyster (Big 🦪 fan!), sip “Stoutie” pints with our selfies imprinted onto the foamie heads (had to sip my face off, sorry…), chill in the circular Gravity Lounge overlooking the city and launch a beautifully full first first day in Dublin dedicated to calibrating my stout sipping to place-of-origin standards.

More than a couple Irish friends told me that @mulligans_poolbeg_st est. 1732) poured the best Guinness in Dublin, so we had to check that out. I’ve surely got more pints to to consider but…wow. That pint was so rich it was like a Guinness milkshake.

Along with a lovely dinner overlooking the River Liffey @thewindingstairdublin (see more pics in my story), it was a wonderful first day in Ireland with my son, confirming once again that @elizabethlaban , whose idea it was for this boys trip, has no rivals for Wife and Mother of the Year.

The new tasting menu format suits @hearthsidebyob and has spurred fresh bursts of creativity (with no-weekly changes) that are challenging the Collingswood star in a good way to remain near the top of South Jersey’s currently buzzing dining scene. There were so many great dishes on this 9-course menu in late June. Excellent ingredients, perfectly executed, and crafted in ways both clever and accessible. Nothing too crazy here in the globally influenced dishes. But each was thoughtfully composed and bursting with vivid flavors. They have also added an la carte option to the outside tables, all walk in, to preserve that spontaneous neighborhood vibe that doesn’t always have to be a special occasion blow-out. Seems like a smart compromise.

Loved the…
-the “pasta course” of fregola mixed with charred corn, pesto and smoked ricotta that, when you mixed it all together, was a vibrant twist on elotes
-fried green tomatoes topped with sweet lump crab salad 
-the grilled octopus drenched in roasty salsa macha over shredded papaya and mango salad
-the Wagyu carpaccio dressed like a brothless pho, with Thai basil aioli, jalapeno rings and crunchy shallots (offered to my non-octo-eating wife as an alternative, but I still ate half of it:) 
-perfectly seared  scallops with zucchini and some green froth
-lavender braised duck over delicate tagliatelle in pink peppercorn sauce
-gorgeously roasted duck breast fanned across from a fried grits cake topped with a grilled apricot wrapped in duck prosciutto.
-an ethereally light and flavorful riff on a strawberry Good Humor bar for dessert. 
-BYO @bialevineyards zin, perfectly ripe, dark and spicy for this meal (also, extra points for the complimentary sparkling water).

It’s always a treat to go back to @stina_pizzeria , one of Philly’s best neighborhood restaurants on Snyder Ave. in South Philly where the creative takes on wood-fired Mediterranean flavors from @chef_bobby_saritsoglou are always so appealing.

The pizza is great, of course. But I also especially love his Turkish-style pides, like this one stuffed with house lamb merguez, mozz and tabouleh. 
Other highlights:
-the meaty savor of the Wagyu strip kebab over bulgar risotto studded with the sweetness of golden raisins
-the summery freshness of tuna seared in a pepita dukka crust over pureed peas and summer succotash
-I appreciated the vegetarian mushroom riff on his famous lamb manti, with beech mushrooms and the extra panache of porcini broth poured tableside
-the vibrant Greek chopped salad
-all the Mediterranean dips, with fresh baked pita
-Margherita pizza with buffalo mozzarella, and nice leopard spots
-Stina is byob, and this classic vinho verde from @casal_garcia - crisp, bright and faintly effervescent - was the perfect answer to a hot summer night.

It’s finally tomato season! That means you’ll be seeing a parade of colorful BLTs and similar such colorful odes to summer’s most coveted treasure on my timeline for the next few weeks. There may be no Philly tomato sandwich more fit for a gastronaut than this perfectly trimmed square of pristine heirloom lusciousness @rivertwicephl : a thick steak of golden tomato juiciness layered with lacy sheets of gamtai Korean seaweed (bitter, smoky, oceanic - @greensandbeans79 holds up a sheet of gamtae in pic 7), smoked Duke’s mayo and a giant scoop of golden ossetra caviar on buttery toast. 

My instinct is always that great tomatoes are luxurious enough on their own. But as always… chef Rucker and his talented crew skillfully make the case that the right kind of gilding can take them to another special place. Pure indulgence. A $40 sandwich that was worth every deluxe bite. So was the enormous halibut collar (another add-on) glazed with butter and yet more caviar, whose saline beads added an extra pop to cut the richness of the fish’s moist flesh.

Those were just a couple of the memorable dishes I savored at a recent meal at the RT counter, where the $65 four-course summer menu is a really solid value. Also still thinking about…
-the Maine scallop crudo transformed by the coconut-notes of fig oil and tart gooseberries 
-all the textures of a NJ rice grits porridge that popped with roe and beans, encased in a translucent sheet of lardo
-silky bittersweet chocolate mousse topped with cherries cooked in pine syrup

Also, I was a *little* bitter I missed-out on the last fancy hot dog with bacon XO, though I’m glad it went to @chrissirhc6, my neighbor at RT’s counter who I was happy to see after so many years, a long time removed since the days she was a favorite barista @cafelift. Also, since the sad demise of @primalsupply, the Mother Rucker burger is on pause:(

They had me at “celeriac schnitzel.” And @aptekapgh delivered its unique vegan takes on Central and Eastern European cuisine with a greater depth of soul, finesse, and imagination than I could have hoped for. 

Pittsburgh’s very worthy @beardfoundation finalist (Best Chefs Mid-Atlantic) also turned out to be so much more than I expected. A laidback secret garden fringed with climbing grape vines and a puffing smoker that scented the air around us. A candlelit tent where we feasted with friends @halbklein and @ricogagliano on a dreamy parade of herb-blasted golabkis, kluskis and pierogies. And one of the most distinctive drink lists I’ve come across all year - smartly oriented to Eastern European natural wines like Croatian Babić and skin-contact Hungarian Királyleányka - but also with stellar cocktails infused with house dandelion tinctures, juniper and celery seeds. The “whiskey” cocktail with tart cherries, Cornelian cherry cordial and vermouth was our champ. When co-chef and co-owner @kate_lasky talks about “having a meeting with our cherry guy soon” you know a serious fruit haul is in the works.

And the food from Lasky and her co-chef/co-owner Tomascz Skowronski? It was memorably fantastic, primarily inspired by Polish flavors (though it journeys beyond) and totally worth the detour. There is no restaurant I’ve been to anywhere else like it.

Among my favorites were:
-The boiled potato-cabbage pierogi plate with horseradish beets and spicy czarina salsa topped with a “double fat” dollop of creamy yogurt made from almonds and cashews.
-the celery root schnitzel, of course (so satisfying I want to recreate it at home; good luck to me!) 
-Yeasted paszteciki buns stuffed with sauerkraut and carrots
- Summer stew with beans and zucchini and golden beets, and a chilled beet soup
- early summer cabbage roll golabki cigars stuffed with kohlrabi, rice, fermented carrots, mushrooms and onions
-the tender, saucer-like potato dumplings of Silesian kluski in celeriac puree with fried buckwheat and cauliflower
- crumb cake with Hungarian blue plum jam and amazingly creamy sunflower seed ice cream.

We came for our annual Summer Sweeties, those chilled oysters on the half-shell @sweetamaliamarket topped with melon salsa and jalapeño. We came for the epic BLT, whose thick-cut Shirley’s tomatoes and basil mayo dripped their ripe summer juices down my wrist… But, of course, there are so many other delights at this South Jersey roadside gem, a mainstage for local oyster craft that’s also a sandwich haven, a stellar market for artisan local ingredients (from produce to an awesome cheese case), and just pure magic when summer blooms with the ripest ingredients and every picnic tables in the yard is packed with happy diners. A perfect setting for an oyster road trip Sunday.

Today, there were also luxurious seared Cape May scallops over silky corn cream with pickled corno di toro peppers, which resemble the vegetal savor of long hots but without the heat. There were @sweetamaliaoysters  delicately baked with smoked chili and scallion butter. And there was a perfect gazpacho that @elizabethlaban declared her favorite ever... 

But the best bite of them all is my new favorite sandwich here: a remarkable eggplant cutlet with fresh mozz and broccoli rabe pesto so good, I could literally taste it in my mind all the way home, back over the Walt Whitman Bridge. Good work “eggplant ambassador” @tommymc730 ! And also thanks to @melissamcgrathchef for never letting up and making this special place even better every year. It wasn’t easy, though, to get my crew to return from oyster shack paradise: @buttercupofrittenhouse , as you can see from the final pic enjoying the market’s cool concrete floor, did not want to come home!

Give me all the deep-fried fish heads leftover from your omakase tasting @royal_izakaya! And also plenty of Wet Naps. This kitchen special at Queen Village’s famed Japanese tavern is a messy, wonderful, all hands-on event as one goes on the treasure hunt through the jeweled pockets of sublimely juicy flesh hiding in the cheeks, cranium nooks and collars of this bountiful platter of perfectly crisped bream. At $28, the kabuto-age is actually a deal. It’s no wonder they serve it last. 

Only challenge: we were so full from all the other menu delights we’d already devoured….
-the bulls-eye crunch of finely shaved scallions at wrapped in fatty pink tuna ring of negi toro
-the salt-broiled mackerel, possibly Philly’s most underrated fish dish, saba shioyaki
- “Industry chirashi” the late-night-only $19 bargain of seasoned rice topped with scraps from the tasting menu (which just went up to $230…😳), narrated by our excellent server, Samantha 
-spinach gomaee glazed in black sesame dressing
-the custardy scoop of chilled sukui tofu splashed with dashi and tiny mushrooms (perfect for summer) 
-cucumber sunomono with vinegar dressing and crunchy barley 
-shogayaki pork in ginger sauce
- some well-crafted cocktails (the absinthe-tinged, sake-fueled coupe of Paragons of Normalcy was my favorite)
-yuzu-nori butter broiled Sweet Amalia oysters
-Taiyaki Sundae, of dense fish-shaped pancakes with scoops of house-vanilla ice cream glazed in strawberry miso caramel and crunchy gold stars. 

The izakaya, unlike the seemingly impossible-to-reserve omakase, is walk-in only. And we lucked-out. A table for four had cleared just as we arrived to make a deliciously epic mess of our own.

Give this Delta Dynasty a crown 👑: if there’s a better bowl of seafood and grits in the Philly region than this beauty @foodchasers_kitchen I haven’t found it. Big, beautiful shrimp. A well-crisped fillet of tasty fresh catfish. Impressively plump sweet lumps of crab. And a sunny orange sauce that brought a zesty swagger, rather than hot spice, to compliment those creamy grits. 

I’m so glad to have finally visited this seriously hyped brunch cafe from twin sisters and former school principals, Drs. Maya and Kala Johnston, the irrepressible duo behind the popular @foodchasers Instagram account. Perched in a breezy space with an al fresco deck near the Elkins Park train station, their BYOB has garnered major buzz from visiting music stars and local athletes, like Eagles QB1 @jalenhurts , who created a signature cheesesteak for them with… mayo?! I still can’t endorse mayo on a cheesesteak. But the Jalen was definitely better than I expected - the meat itself quite tender and flavorful. But there were several other items I’d recommend first, like the salmon cheesesteak full of bountiful fresh fish, the biscuit special covered in turkey sausage gravy, or any of their chicken tender creations glazed in spicy honey - we loved the FCK over biscuits, and the variation atop French toast. 

Kudos to the Food Chasers’ staff, which was universally charming and outgoing - and so, so kind to @buttercupofrittenhouse who devoured their cheesy scrambled eggs (four 🐾 🐾 up!) as she angled for some shade beneath the picnic table on the deck. We also got to meet the twins, who emerged from their kitchen all smiles and hospitality, despite the obvious glow of cooking a hot brunch in August. They nonetheless seemed to revel in the hands-on challenge of doing it all themselves: “When we stop washing the dishes ourselves,” one joked to the other, “it’s all downhill from there!”

I doubt it. Food Chasers Kitchen has a good thing going in Elkins Park. 

All pics mine, save for an official @phillyrover portrait of this duo from a 2022 piece by @phillyinquirer colleague @phillyinsider, which is worth a read for more details.

Summer isn’t over until the broth comes back, and “brothless summer” @neighborhoodramen still runs through Labor Day. [note: actually not. Just Learned NR is now closed for vacation until 9/9…so summer *is* over! 😢]. 

Of course, it goes without saying that NeighRam is fantastic all four seasons. But I always get an extra snap of appreciation for their next-level house-pressed noodles (a rarity in the ramen world) when they’re more open to view. They have such a special texture. Their topping are also vividly flavorful and balanced. And I love all these combos, including the seasonal riff on elotes (pic #3,4) I ate a couple weeks ago. The noodles topped with a fan of moist, chili-dusted chicken (pic #2) were also fantastic, but may not be available for the end-of-summer home stretch this week (based on current online menu). However….. Definitely *do* try the Hiyashi Chuka (#1 pic), a gorgeous cold salad take on wavy ramen topped with a pinwheel of ingredients - cucumber, tomato, nori, pork, naruto and tamago - with a refreshing shoyu vinaigrette. And, of course, the Taiwan Mazesoba (#5) of hot noodles topped with gochugaru-spiced ground pork and jidori egg yolk mixed is also amazing, like the love child of tantan and carbonara I’ll be dreaming of until summer rolls around again. 

Also, don’t forget those spicy pickles (#7)!

A belated Feliz Cumpleaños to @elcantinflasbar ! This sweet Puerto Rican restaurant and bar has anchored a Kensington corner in the shade of the York-Dauphin El station for 19 years now, and I’m embarrassed it took me nearly that long to visit there myself. But after feasting on chef-owner Migdalia “Daly” Morales’s crackling good pork chops and mofongo in recent months, I am glad I finally did. It was one of the highlight stops on my recent #TastePhilly newsletter series (sign-up link in bio!). So, better late than never. Thanks for the tip @levinson.aaron!

Initially El Cantinflas became known for its Puerto Rican-style tacos, which wrap various sofrito-seasoned meats bound with adobo mashed potatoes and fixings inside sauce soft tortillas. They’re truly tasty in a non-Mexican, updated Taco Supreme kind of way. 

But the ultimate move here is anything with plantains. The mofongo is so good because it’s made fresh from plantains that are peeled, fried and mashed to order, with crunchy, crushed-that-moment chicharrónes and @mordaly’s zesty, secret, buttery garlicky sauce. I love it with a steel crock of garlicky shrimp or tender carne frita on the side. But then there are the crispy pressed plantain cups stuffed with shrimp in Creole sauce. Or the latke-like cakes of shredded plantain laced with adobo called aranitas. Or some of El Cantinflas’ other fried delights - like the empanadas and alcapurrias stuffed with moist crab. It is also quite possible that Morales now also cooks one of the best pork chops in Philly. She seasons the thick, fresh-cut chops well with sazón and they with pop with savor after a crisping dunk in the fryer, to be paired with arroz and beans bobbing with tiny chicken salchichas, which are like little wieners with a spicy attitude.

This a family operation through and through, a second-generation business with Daly’s sister out front serving mojitos and coladas with a magnetic smile. I also want to return when El Cantinflas’ big al fresco patio across the street is rocking. Maybe next year for this neighborhood gem’s 20th birthday?

location.city_name: The Franklin Fountain Ice Cream, Old Town

social_posts.post_text:
The @franklinfountain remains undefeated as the greatest all-around ice cream 🍨 experience in Philly. And though I love many of our next-Gen ice cream wizards (@milkjawn @weckerlys & @cuzzysicecream to name just a few), a scoop of the Franklin’s Honeycomb ice cream - in full fall trickle down the side of my cone - is quite simply food of the Gods.  The very best. The honey is drawn from Franklin’s rooftop hives by @philadelphiabee. Love the Berley Bros. commitment to all the details in their vintage space, the pleasant and efficient service, the ample gluten-free and vegan options, and just the overall Old City-at-its-best vibe. As you can see in pic 2, @buttercupofrittenhouse has her snout buried deep into a carton of vanilla, and clearly agrees. Like Daddy,
like Doggy.

text_entities.entity: deputy features editor & digital design wiz

social_posts.post_text:
Have you renewed your passport lately? It’s a challenge these days and you better plan well ahead if you’re hoping to go abroad. Our #TastePhilly newsletter, though, will take you for a spin around the world without ever leaving the Philly region - complete with these cool passport stamps crafted by @phillyinquirer graphics wiz @swmadden to mark every step of the journey. 

We launched this 7-part series earlier this year, and what an in-box trip it’s been, from the local soup dumpling wars to Philly’s suburban Dosa Belt, @seamarket_FDRpark, Addis Ababa on Baltimore Avenue and beyond! My irrepressible colleague @smashoffman pitched the idea for this newsletter “course” and I jumped right on board. This is my kind of project: to showcase communities from across the globe that have made Philly home, and celebrate those cultures through the lens of one key dish, technique, food space or ingredient. We’re a city built on big immigrant restaurant dreams. But it was great fun to focus in through such a narrow window and see what bigger stories awaited on the other side of a freshly mashed Puerto Rican mofongo, or a Poblano trompo spit loaded with al pastor. Or the century-old Philly-Italian passion for whole fish - and the branzino revolution that followed.

The coolest part? With a course-style newsletter, you haven’t missed a thing. Sign-up now (tap link in my bio) and you’ll get the whole weekly series, beginning at part 1. 

These pics were just some of my most memorable bites along the way …
-colorful xiao long bao @nanxiangsoupdumpling 
-ghee roast dosa cone @ammasphiladelphia 
-Cambodian papaya salad pounded @seamarket_fdrpark 
- @_fia_neth of @sophieskitchenphilly , my FDR Park guide, savoring sweet purple sticky rice from the heart of a bamboo
-a 2lb. wild spigola bass roasted over crispy potatoes @lanimaphilly_ 
-mofongo with garlic shrimp and chicken chicharrones @elcantinflasbar 
-al pastor al trompo spit kissed by fire at Deanna’s Market in Toughkenamon
-an Ethiopian feast (with city’s best raw kitfo) over injera @ Amsale Cafe in West Philly

Three Alarm Thanksgiving: I can’t believe I’ve been cooking this meal for my family for 22 years! Partly because time flies. But also because every year, something that goes awry. Last year, the fancy new @bbq.guru temperature controller I bought to replace a trusty old manual version for my Big Green Egg refused to connect to the app (still not working, so it was basically useless, again). This year, I charred the sherry-charred Brussels sprouts a bit too enthusiastically. “It’s getting smoky in here!” @elizabethlaban always tells me. “It’s fine! I’ve got the fan on high!” I always say, blasting the pan on full flame, opening the kitchen door and windows, until… ding! ding! ding! ding! The fire alarm went off. Thankfully our alarm company was able to wave off the fire department before Ladder 5 came to our house. 

Our dinner guests, though? Oh yes, they came! We definitely missed my folks, who can no longer travel & were back in Detroit with my Chicago-based sister’s crew. But it was a fine extended Philly family feast nonetheless, as we dove for starters into a new fixture this year: the punch bowl made to the rummy-peach recipe I recently published with @tobycocktail. My Godshall’s turkey was a charcoal roasted beauty, scented with herbes de Provence and kissed with cherry smoke, properly cooked without any gadget assistance. There were carrots and caramelized garlic heads from drip pan, roasted wild mushrooms, andouille-corn bread stuffing (a nod to our NOLA days) and milk-stewed, dried sweet Cope’s Corn, a tradition I covet from the Pennsylvania Dutch half of Elizabeth’s Reading family. But my favorite side this year was Elizabeths’s potato filling. Her aunts used to argue about who made it better, and this recipe was handed-down by my late-mother-in-law Barbara Trostler, who taught her daughter well. I can now officially say Elizabeth yesterday made best potato filling ever, baked to a golden brown on top, but rich inside with butter, eggs (plus cubed gluten-free bread) and soooo fluffy inside.

The house still smells like roasted Brussels sprouts this morning. And I’m grateful another successful Thanksgiving is in the books.

“Real Tex-Mex food is an American treasure,” says @tacotrailofficial.

And from where I sat next to my friend José, the taco editor @texasmonthly who’d brought us into the heart of Houston restaurant tradition @ninfasoriginal,
I could only agree. There was the crock of molten queso flameado being folded into itself tableside with peppers and chorizo then folded-up into warm handmade flour tortilla rolls rich and translucent with lard. There were supple and saucy enchiladas in chile gravy (one of José’s Tex-Mex litmus tests), and of course tacos al carbon, the proto-fajitas dish Ninfa’s famously created in 1973. I’ve had so many lame chain fajitas over the years elsewhere - but not this one. The ribbons of grilled skirt steak were fragrant with the smoke of real charcoal and fire-toasted cumin. A busy 50-year-old standby like Ninfa’s doesn’t need to be this good - but I’m glad I got to experience such genuine flavors, especially on my first trip to Texas. 
What a delight to also discover over the past four days in Houston that this town’s dining scene is so dynamic and diverse. The morning after Tejano platter paradise at Ninfa’s, I was eating creative Cambodian fusion pastries and palate-teasing savory lattes @koffeteria. Pho beef kolaches? Thai banana sticky rice Danish? A “tamalwich” wrapped in a crispy sheet of griddled Oaxaca cheese sandwiched between sweet soufflé pancakes? Yes, please! 

And there were so many other highlights. 
-hauntingly smoked Texas brisket and jalapeno cheddar links from @truth_bbq 
-shrimp aguachile @jun_bykin 
-the yellowedge grouper duo + coconut-glazed chicken with anchovy sauce @trexhouston 
-puffy Nancy hoe cakes with trout roe and whipped butter, plus some chile-piqued beef dumplings with sauerkraut, yogurt and dill @nancyshustle. Also, the absinthe-kissed Grand Century @julephou all decorated in its festive holiday lights. Aside from being a great food town, I sipped sparkling Texas natty mourvedre @lightsome_wines, and so many Texas beers @westalabamaicehouse, and a Michelada tinted with fish sauce and hoisin (@ Jūn), Houston is clearly also a fantastic place to drink!

How about a sweet finish to 2023? 
I’m not generally a big dessert guy. I’m not even really that much of a chocolate fiend. But *this* chocolate cake - and these other desserts - delivered a little extra magic in their simple excellence that resonated with me over the past couple months as spectacular finales to some enjoyable meals. 

-double chocolate cake at the revived @royaltavern : super moist sponge, super silky chocolate silk, clever little crunchies to scattered among the fluted icing peaks.
-Basque cheesecake from @phillytartas Hatim Hamdan, who’s also sous-cheffing for @nuongphl @tlwincubator : like cheesecake and pudding had a baby, but richer, more seductive, and with a slow motion custard flow that is an absolute fork magnet. Deserves its own Incubator showcase.
-pistachio gelato @levirtuphila, now under new exec chef @where.time.becomes.a.loop (Andrew Wood): the nut factor is dialed-up to 11. The pistachio flavor in these frozen scoops is so intense. So dense, creamy, almost fudgey. Southern Italy is calling. And it’s irresistible. 
-rye cannoli @highstreetphl with chocolate-chai cream, apple butter and black tea caramel: if you’re going to mess with a Philly classic, go all the way. This beauty from @its.a.dill.pickle does just that with a paper-thin delicate shell and garnishes that ride the cheffy line of sweet and savory without ever landing on the wrong side. An extreme example of the rye flour trend I noted in my favorite flavors of the year piece I posted @phillyinquirer this week. 
-espresso flan over flourless chocolate brownie @elchingonphilly : you probably can’t resist the Nutella-stuffed concha with strawberries. Get that, too. But @jcarlosaparicio is such a pastry wiz, it’s no surprise his densely creamy, coffee-powered flan is so rico. It’s also gluten-free.
Hungry Man for Hire, Deadline Drinker, Duck Influencer, Hoagie-centric, Phila Inquirer restaurant critic. “Destiny has brought me this lamb chop.”
